titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Mr Harris brought me this morning the dispatch from the joint mission for the Secretary of State, with the six documents annexed, which I read over, and then signed and closed the dispatch— Mr Redwood called twice, at Noon and at 3 in the afternoon at which time I gave him all the remainder of the letters and dispatches prepared for him— He went down to Cronstadt this Evening. Mr: Calhoun came to tell me of his intention to go to Stockholm and Copenhagen in about a fortnight— I walked in the Summer Gardens after dinner.

2. Mrs: Adams and Mrs Smith, with Charles went out and dined with Countess Colombi. Baron Blome paid me a visit to inform me that he was recalled. Mr Lisakewitz the Russian Minister at Copenhagen received an order from the Emperor, through Count Nesselrode to quit that Country— It was dated 7. August, in consequence of which he Baron Blome was likewise ordered to ask for his Passports— He should write this day to Count Romanzoff, and ask for a vessel with a safe-conduct; for he could not return either through Sweden or through Prussia, where there is a Swedish army. He keeps the house that he has taken and all his furniture, thinking that the War will not be long— For either Denmark will be utterly destroyed, and he must come out of it as he can; or the allies will be successful and will make Peace with her, or they will be unsuccessful which may lead to a result of the same kind— He promised to send me the Berlin Gazettes containing the French news from Spain— They claim a victory on the 28th: of July; but so faintly that it portends perhaps a defeat— The English Accounts at least pretend so— Blome thinks that whatever may happen the Swedish Crown Prince at least is sure of having great success— I had also a visit from Mr: Montreal— After my evening walk I went to the lodgings of Messrs: Gallatin and Bayard, and spent the remainder of it with them— They had called at my house, and I met them returning home— Mr Gallatin shewed me the Copy of his letter to Mr Baring, and a letter which he has received from General Moreau, who is at the Emperor Alexander’s Head Quarters— He says he has come to fight Bonaparte, and does it without the least repugnance— That if he contributes his share to overthrow Bonaparte, he shall have the thanks of France, as well as of the rest of the World— Peu importe la baniere, lorsqu’on réüssit. The rest of his letter is upon American politics— We had much Conversation upon this topic, and I sat with the Gentlemen, untill near one in the Morning— Mr Harris was there.

3. Captain Stanwood came and requested me to obtain a Courier’s Passport for him. He is going through Sweden to England; and will be ready to go next Wednesday— Mr Cabot is to go with him— Mr Lewis also came and passed an hour with me this morning.— I walked after dinner in the Summer-Gardens, and finished the day at Nine O’Clock.

4. I received this Morning an Answer from Count Romanzoff to the application I had made in behalf of Mr de Tracy. The Emperor has granted permission for him to come from Tambow to St: Petersburg, and to lodge at my house— Mr Todd came and spent an hour of the Evening with us. I employed part of the day in writing. Mrs Helm left us, after having lived nearly two years in the house— She is one of the best Servants we have had.— I walked after dinner in the Summer Gardens.

5. Being still unwell I did not walk out untill after dinner— Read prayers for the 12th: Sunday after Trinity— Employed the remainder of the day in consulting Goguet, the Dictionnaire Historique, and Diodorus Siculus, to trace the origin of alphabetical writing. I obtained no very satisfactory information.

6. Morning visit from Mr Montreal— Also Mr Lys called upon me from Messrs. Colombi and Zea, respecting General Pardo’s books, which I had agreed to take— I finished the transaction with him. Mr Lewis was likewise here. I wrote a Note to Count Romanzoff asking a Passport for Captain Stanwood, and requesting to see him. He sent me an Answer, appointing half past five this afternoon at his house in the Country— I was engaged to dine at Mr Raimbert’s, but thought I could leave the table in time to go to the Count’s— I did leave the table, but not untill a quarter before seven; and it was ten minutes past seven when I reached the Count’s house— He had waited for me untill seven, and then went out to Madame Narishkin’s, his Aunt’s— I went from thence to see Mr Gallatin and Mr Bayard— Young Gallatin is very unwell; with some fever. On returning home I found Captain Jones and his Midshipman Nicholson; Captain Stanwood and his Son— They made a short visit.— I had a letter of 13. August from Mr Beasley.

7. I wrote this Morning a Note to Count Romanzoff, apologizing for having called at his house so late last Evening, and asking for a new appointment of Time; but before I had sent it, I received a note from him apologizing to me for not having been at home when I called, and appointing one O’Clock this afternoon, at his house in the City— I went at that time, and after thanking him for the permission which the Emperor had granted for Mr de Tracy to come to St: Petersburg, I asked him, if by that of his lodging at my
house it was understood that he would be restricted from lodging elsewhere if it should be more agreeable to himself— The count said no— That was only a Compliment to me; as there might otherwise appear some impropriety that a prisoner of War should lodge at the house of a foreign Minister. The Emperor had done the same thing to the Princess de Tarente, by sending a Mr: de Castres to lodge at her house; at which she had been quite thrown into Consternation— She having in such excessive horror all the present state of things in France, and having taken this interest in favour of Mr: de Castres, not from any regard for him whom she did not know, but for his father who had been her friend.— I also asked the Count if any thing further was necessary to be done to give Mr de Tracy notice that he might come to St: Petersburg— He said he would immediately write a letter to the Minister at War, to enquire whether he had received any order on the subject— He called in one of his Clerks and directed him to write the letter for him to sign.— We had little conversation besides— He told me that Mr Gallatin had called upon him this morning and had mentioned to him the substance of the letter he had received from Mr Baring— But he the Count, still thought the British Government would eventually accept the Mediation; and he supposed their reluctance to it hitherto might have arisen from their habit of considering the People of the United States as a part of themselves, and all their differences with them as a sort of family quarrel. Yet by their proposal of treating at Gothenburg, he thought they might be willing to treat under the Mediation of the Crown Prince of Sweden, or the Swedish Government. I told him they had already refused that— The Count spoke of the last Battles in Spain as not decisive in their issue; and said there were no official Accounts from the Armies in Germany— He had heard of private letters from Memel and Königsberg saying that the Crown Prince had taken 6000 Prisoners; but he thought it was no more than that the French had attempted to penetrate towards Berlin and had been repulsed.— The Count complained of having been very ill, and said he was still quite indisposed. Captain Jones, and William Nicholson, Captain Stanwood and his son Theodore—Mr Lewis and Mr Rogers, whom I for some time mistook for Mr Roberts, dined with us, and passed the Evening untill ten— Mr Lewis had a letter from Carlscrona, saying there had been a Battle near Rostock, in which the Allies were defeated— But no Battle of any importance could have been fought near Rostock.

8. Morning visit from Mr Montreal. We all dined at Mr Krehmer’s in the Country. Mr Gallatin and Mr Bayard, with Messrs: Harris, Dallas, Milligan and Todd were there— Mr Gallatin’s son is still confined with a fever— Mr Lewis was also of the Company—and Mrs Fisher, Miss Bock, a Miss Bush and Mrs. Krehmer’s youngest Sister Miss Fock.— A MissSister of the General, came in after dinner— We went very late and sat long at table— Mr Krehmer gave me the Austrian Manifesto against France— Rumours of victories near Berlin and in Silesia are still afloat; but no account of any important action has arrived— When we returned home I received a note from the Duke de Serra-Capriola, saying that the other foreign Ministers here had agreed to go on Saturday next, without invitation to the Church of St: Alexander Nevsky, to the celebration of the Emperor’s name day; as a mark of attention to the two Empresses— And proposing to me to join in the Compliment.

9. I sent to Mr Gallatin for the dispatches of the joint mission to be forwarded by Captain Stanwood—when they came I found on examination that one of the papers was wanting— I wrote Mr Harris a Note asking for it— Mr Gallatin answered me that it had been forgotten. I promised to keep the packet open, untill Captain Stanwood should call for the Papers, and if it should not then be ready, to dispatch the packet without it— Captain Florance came for a Passport which I gave him— I wrote to Mr Beasley— On returning from my walk after dinner with Charles I found Mr Krabbe here— He enquired about the opportunity I had mentioned to Baron Blome, of writing to Copenhagen— It was by Mr Colhoun; and I promised Mr Krabbe to let the Baron know, when he would be ready to go. The Communications with Denmark are now so entirely cut off, that the Baron has no means of writing to his Government, but by American opportunities— No others are allowed to pass from Sweden to Denmark.— Mr Todd and Dr Laughton passed the Evening here.

10. Captain Stanwood wrote me a note apologizing for having been detained longer than he had expected; so that he had not come for the dispatches. In my walk after dinner to the Summer Gardens I met Mr Montréal. I have wasted the leisure of this and of several former days in reading Scott’s last Poem of Rokeby; and the Burlesque upon it Jokeby. The Burlesque is very good as a Parody; and exposes some of the faults of the original poem.

11. At a quarter past eleven this morning, I went with Mr Smith, and attended the celebration of the Emperor’s name day, at the Monastery of St: Alexander Nevsky. It was within ten minutes of twelve when we came there, and the crowd made the church almost inaccessible— The Empresses, the Grand-Dukes Nicholas and Michael, and the Grand Duchess Ann came in about half an hour— There was a Mass; a consecration of the medals, and a Te Deum— The medals are of silver, about the size of half a Ruble, struck in Commemoration of the Campaign and deliverance of 1812. On one side is an eye inclosed within a triangle, an emblem of God’s Providence; and on the other, the inscription in Russian “Not unto us, Not unto us, but unto thy name.”—this medal is to be distributed, and worn suspended by a blue silk ribbon at the button hole, by every individual who took part in the Campaign of 1812. from the highest Officer to the private Soldier inclusive— The Emperor’s Ukaze concerning this medal was read by the Minister at War, Gortschakoff. The consecration was performed by the Metropolitan Ambrose— The Mass had been said by another Archbishop.— The Imperial family performed their prostrations at the shrine of the Saint— The Courtiers were all radiant with good news from the Armies— The Emperor within hearing of the Bells of Dresden, and the French defeated in all quarters, with the certain expectation of more important victories in a few days.— It was past 3 O’Clock when we got home— Captain Stanwood had been here; but does not go, untill Monday Night. I walked after dinner, and called on Messieurs Gallatin and Bayard, but they were abroad— I saw Mr James Gallatin, who is confined to the house with a fever— I met Mr Krabbe in my walk, and he sent me afterwards the Berlin Gazettes of August 28 and 30.— Napoleon’s drama draws to its Catastrophe.

12. I read prayers for the 13th: Sunday after Trinity. Dined at Count Romanzoff with a Company of about sixty persons, the usual anniversary dinner for the Emperor’s name day. There was a hand-bill before dinner with the account of General Blücher’s victory of 26 August, but with no other particulars than those I had seen last Night in the Papers sent me by Mr Krabbe— I sat between Count Alexander Soltykoff and the Minister of the Interior Mr Kosodavleff. The band of music performed in the adjoining chamber, during the whole dinner— After the Emperor’s health had been drank, according to the usual custom, in Champaign, the Company all rising, a Court footman came in with a Note from the Empress-Mother to the Count, which he immediately opened and read aloud to the Company— Its purport was— “Thanks be rendered to the most high— Our dear Emperor is in good health— He has won the most compleat victory over our Enemies—80 pieces of Cannon— Several Generals 2000 prisoners, &c— I am in too great emotion to say more— Praised for ever be the Supreme Being.” Immediately afterwards a second Note was read by Count Markoff, which came I believe from the Old Field Marshal Count Soltykoff— It repeated the same tidings of victory; with the addition of Blucher’s Victory in Silesia, and another Victory won by the Crown Prince of Sweden— This note added that among the Generals taken Prisoners was Van Damme, who was already sent off to Moscow— That the Victory was decided by the Regiments of Guards, Preobrajensky, and Semenoffsky and the Regiment of Chasseurs which had highly distinguished themselves.— Count Romanzoff called up the footman who brought the Note, gave him a glass of wine, and embraced him, kissing him on both cheeks. A second glass of Champaign was ordered all round the table, and the Emperor was toasted over again— A tempest of exultation burst forth from all quarters, and it was universally agreed that Bonaparte’s Career was now finished— The Empress Mother’s Note was passed from hand to hand; and instead of 2000 prisoners as Count Romanzoff had read it was found to be 4000 or 9000.— In the midst of the hurly-burly came a Note to Mr Kosodavleff the Minister of the interior, from the Director of the Post-Office, saying nothing more than that the Courier left Töplitz the 18/30th. this Circumstance cast some little damp upon the tumult of joy that was raging. How the Courier should have come from Töplitz occasioned some surprize— It was remarked that there were three Töplitzes, one in Bohemia, one in Saxony, and one in Silesia; and the question was from which of them the Courier came— Then it was noticed that neither the Empresses, nor Marshal Soltykoff’s note mentioned either time or place at which the battle was fought— General Armfeldt said that Töplitz was forty Versts from Dresden; but it is at least sixty. It was known that before the battle the Emperor Alexander was
at the gates of Dresden, and his troops were bombarding the City. Why the Courier after the Battle should have come from Töplitz was not enquired into nor accounted for. It was said that the Russian Accounts never gave dates either of time or place— It was unanimously concluded however that there was now a total dissolution of the French Army; and the doubt and distrust occasioned by the name of Töplitz was perceptible only on the countenance, and in the eyes of two or three persons— I came from the Count’s immediately home— Mr Gallatin sent me in the Evening the paper which was wanting to complete the duplicates of our dispatch to be sent by Captain Stanwood.

13. Early this morning I received a notification from the department of the Ceremonies, for a Te Deum at the Cazan Church at twelve O’Clock— I attended it with Mr Smith. All the mystery of the Courier’s having come from Töplitz was explained by Count Litta. The Russian, Austrian and Prussian Head-Quarters were at Töplitz— The victory of the 30th. of August was complete— The divisions of Victor and Van Damme totally destroyed. Van Damme himself and seven other Generals prisoners with 7000 men—80 pieces of Cannon— Standards, Eagles and Ammunition waggons— The Allies had commenced the siege of Dresden, and had taken one of the outworks— Gouvion St: Cyr had thrown himself with 30,000 men into Dresden—on the 27th: Napoleon came with 60000 men, and 10,000 Curassiers, and attacked the allies before Dresden—they fought the whole day and he made no impression— He renewed the Attack the 28th: with no better success. The 29th: he turned about, crossed the Elbe at Königstein, marched down the river side; crossed it again and entered Bohemia— The Russian Army followed him down on the other side of the river— Kleist with the Prussians at the same time went down and crossed the Mountains— Schwartzenberg and the Austrians came in a still different direction, and on the 30th: from all quarters at once attacked the French army; which was entirely cut to pieces and in a state of total dissolution— Barclai de Tolli covered himself with immortal glory— The three Nations rivalized with each other in atchievements— The Grand Duke Constantine distinguished himself at the head of the Guards, and the Emperor has given him a sword of honour, and a cypher on the shoulder. The Emperor Francis has promised to erect a monument in honour of the Russian Guards, on the plains of Töplitz where the Battle was fought— He said to the Emperor Alexander, “I put my person, my armies, and my dominions into your hands.” In a Postscript, the Emperor Alexander says, they are still bringing in Prisoners by thousands, found dispersed about in the woods— Blücher on his side has defeated the French in Silesia—and as I dismount my horse I learn that the Swedish Crown Prince has defeated Oudinot, taken 25 pieces of Cannon &c— Count Litta further said he had read an intercepted letter from a certain General Catar to Lauriston— A long letter which concluded by saying—I cannot disguise to your Excellency that three fourths of the Soldiers can no longer be made to fight— They throw away their arms, and neither intreaties, nor threats, nor honour, nor blows can bring them to their duty— They say that it is better to be taken prisoners than to perish with hunger, and misery.— My heart is rent with affliction, but your Excellency may nevertheless rely upon it that I shall do my duty.”— Count Litta said that all this was charming news, but when the details would come, then would be the time for the heart-aches of wives and mothers, and Sisters— It was impossible that such a Battle of four days, should have been won without great losses— Only one General was said to be killed; a General Melissino— Count Ostermann had lost an Arm, and General Moreau both his legs— He was at the Emperor’s side, on the 27th. and had just dismounted his horse, when a Cannon Ball carried away his two feet— His two legs were amputated the same day, and on the 30th: the Emperor writes that Wiley gives him more and more hopes of his recovery.— The Emperor had made him his first Aid de Camp General, and Count Litta said the accident which had befallen him was unfortunate in itself, by the loss of his Services, and of the impression he might have made on the French troops; but it was terrifying when it was considered where he was— Whose turn might it be to-morrow?— What might the next Courier have to bring?— It was wrong for Commanders in Chief to expose their own persons without necessity—and it could never be necessary but by way of example, when the soldiers did not of themselves shew sufficient ardour.— The Te Deum was like all the rest, and we came home about 3 O’Clock—the weather confined me at home the rest of the day.

14. After having taken Charles to school this morning I was confined to the house the remainder of the day— The Summer is already gone, and the rainy Season is setting in. My health is drooping in a manner which deeply affects my Spirits, because it
precludes me from those occupations which would make every hour pass lightly away— The long Evenings are again at hand, and threaten to become insupportably burdensome— I have formed the project of paying for some time particular attention to Chronology, and this day took in hand Lenglet du Dufresnoy, and Count John Potocki.— I also continue to read Jortin’s Remarks on Ecclesiastical History.— I had a morning visit from Mr Montreal.

15. Captain Stanwood and Mr Cabot came this morning for their Passport, which I gave them, with the dispatches and letters for America— Captain Stanwood has been detained here, by an accident to the ship in which he is to go to the Havanna; and will probably be further detained some days at Fredericshamm— Mr Colhoun was here, and informed me of his intention to go for Stockholm and Copenhagen, next Monday; and also Mr Willing who proposes to go by Water; and expects to depart next Wednesday— Both these Gentlemen are desirous of obtaining Courier’s Passports— After dinner I called upon Mr Krabbe, and mentioned to him Mr Colhoun’s intention of going next Monday— Mr Lewis passed the Evening with us.

16. I went this morning to Mr Meyer’s, and gave him the list of seeds sent me by Mr Wolcott, requesting him to obtain information, and let me know if all or any of them are to be procured here— I had also some other business to transact with him— On my return I stopp’d at the Academy of Arts, which is open for the annual exhibition of pictures and of sculpture— Met Count Romanzoff there; who told me there was no further news from the Emperor’s army. He spoke with concern of General Moreau’s unfortunate accident— The Pictures at the Academy are in the same Style as those of the preceding years and in general as badly executed— The subjects of the historical pieces are mostly taken from the Events of the last year— Church jewels robbed, and priests murdered by French Soldiers— Peasants turning Soldiers, receiving benedictions from Priests, and parting from their families. There are some Portraits, but none of the Generals who have risen to Fame in the year— The greatest likenesses are the High Chamberlain Narishkin and Count Romanzoff in Crayons. I walked an hour after dinner, an exercise which from the rapid shortening of the days, I shill soon be obliged to forego.

17. Mrs Adams went out to Mrs Krehmer’s to solicit of Mrs Fisher that she would allow the discharge of a Servant whom she had had arrested by the Police, on the charge of having stolen some of Mr Fisher’s effects after his Death— The man has been to implore my interference to obtain his release, and I believe him innocent— But the only manner in which I could interfere was by solicitation in this manner— Mrs Fisher promised he should be discharged— Mr Harris and Mr Lewis passed the Evening with us— I have been two days ascertaining with precision the Turkish and Arabian computation of Time, which is very fully explained, and very correctly in Lenglet Dufresnoy’s Tables— He has brought down the years of the Hegira to 1170. corresponding to the year 1756. and I have continued the list down to the year 1230 of the Hegira 1230 corresponding to 14. Decr: 1814. I rectified my dates by those of our Treaties with Morocco, Algiers, and Tripoli— That with Tunis dates only of the Months— I found them all correct, excepting that with Algiers which is dated 21. of the Moon Safer 1210 which is said to correspond with 5 Septr: 1795—by my computations it should correspond with 6. Septr:— But as they reckon their day from Evening to Evening the 21st: of Safer may have begun 5. Septr: and finished on the sixth— Unless this accounts for it, I must have made a mistake in the calculation— Their mode of measuring time by lunar years, their cycle of 30 years, and their arrangement of the intercalary days are ingenious and in many respects convenient; but very defective by omitting all attempt to combine it with the Solar year.

18. I wrote a note this morning to Count Romanzoff, requesting a Passport for Mr Colhoun. Mr Lewis called upon me to make some enquiries respecting the state of the commercial arrangements between this Country and Spain and Portugal; of which I gave him all the information that I have.— I went with Charles to the Exhibition at the Academy of Arts— The most pleasing Picture there is an Allegory of Beneficence (a flattered portrait of the Empress) descending from Heaven, and crowned by Religion— The best executed, is a figure of Philoctetes in the Island of Lemnos; roaring with the pain of his wound— A classical though not a remarkably well chosen subject— There is a Moozhik in the act of chopping of his own hand, called the Russian Scevola. It is several times repeated both in painting and Sculpture— I suppose a prize subject for the pupils— Many of the pictures are in honour of the Peasants who have contributed so much to the glory of the last year— Painting and Sculpture are all the benefit they are ever likely to derive from their atchievements— They will gain nothing in liberty. It is the opinion of all their owners that they are much happier in their servitude and ignorance, than they would be with freedom and instruction— There were crowds of them at this exhibition; but they did not appear to understand the compliments paid to them in the pictures.

19. I read prayers for the 14th: Sunday after Trinity, and for the remaining part of the day was chiefly employed in writing, to dispatch Mr Colhoun— Read a few pages of Lenglet Dufresnoy, and in comparing his parallel years of the Hegira, and of Christ observed the general return of the same days after an interval of 228 Christian and 235 Turkish years— On further examination I found that this was only the multiplication by the 12 Months, of the Cycle of 19 years marked in all the Almanachs by the golden number. This led me to further enquiries and calculations which absorbed time and diverted my application from its primary object—

20. I had morning visits from Mr Colhoun, Mr Hurd, Mr Willing with Mr Rogers, and Mr Lewis, with Mr Barthe, Mr Clapier and Mr Roberts. Received a letter from Mr Speyer, enclosing others from Mr Forbes and Mr Beasley, and a dispatch from the Secretary of State—the triplicate of one before received— Mr Colhoun called a second time— I gave him his Passport, which I had received from Count Romanzoff, and a packet sent me by Baron Blome, which I enclosed to Mr Forbes— I promised to call on him early to-morrow morning with the rest of my dispatches and letters— After dinner I went and delivered to Mr Gallatin the dispatch received this morning, and a letter to him and Mr Bayard from Mr Forbes— On returning home I found Mr Bayard and Mr Milligan who spent part of the Evening with us— Mr Todd came in afterwards— Mr Barthe and Mr Clapier arrived last Evening from Moscow. Mr Gallatin’s son is still quite unwell— The news of this day is the capture of the Argus; the vessel that brought Mr Crawford out to France. She had previously taken 22 prizes.

21. Called this morning on Mr Colhoun at his lodgings, and delivered him my letters and dispatches— He was going in the course of two or three hours.— Met there an old Servant of mine whom I had not seen these two or three years, Pendorf— He told me he was now employed to copy the words of Music for the performers at the German Theatre— His wages were 800 Rubles a year; but there were some delays in the payments— I wrote part of a letter, and from my Chronological enquiries, have been drawn to Astronomical researches— Consulted the three Volumes of Schubert’s popular Astronomy, and found ample and accumulating materials for further enquiry— In the Evening I was amusing Charles with the descriptive Counters and Tellers of St: Quentin’s Grammar when Nelson the Black man who came with us from America, and entered the Emperor’s service came in— He was permitted nearly a year since to go to England for his health, and has just now returned with part of the Russian fleet.— He says that the Spanish Minister’s Lady, Madame Bardaxi, and Madame de Betancourt with her daughters came in the same Squadron.

22. Mr Willing called upon me this morning. I had written to Count Romanzoff for his Passport, but did not receive it untill the Evening— Besides employing part of the day in writing, I consulted Schubert’s popular Astronomy, and Jortin’s remarks upon Ecclesiastical History— Mrs: Adams and Mrs Smith went out and paid an Evening visit to Madame de Betancourt, who has just returned from England— The news of Victories over the French increases and multiplies every day.

23. Mr Willing called on me this morning. I gave him his Passport and a letter; intending to send the Dispatches to him at Cronstadt— He was going immediately there— The remainder of the day, I was absorbed in Chronological and Astronomical enquiries— I found something upon the subject in the Cours d’Etudes Encyclopédiques of Pagés, and something further and better in the Erudition Universelle of Baron Bielefeld— Pagés has copied whole chapters from this work with some additions which are no improvements— He is one of the anti-religious writers; and every thing in his book relating to religion is bad. Bielefeld though not entirely correct is more modest and candid. Neither of them give the account of which I am in pursuit of the reformations of the Calendar— From Chronology and Astronomy, I was drawn to the tables of Logarithms by Callet— I ascertained the method of finding the logarithm of a number or the number of a logarithm to eight or nine decimals.— I continue to walk in the Summer Gardens after dinner.

24. My Landlord Mr Strugovshikoff came this morning and I settled with him untill next March. An Examination of Callet’s tables engrossed the whole day— I endeavoured to find the method of using his tables of logarithms to 20 decimals, and after a whole day of calculations and of close application partly succeeded— I find it easy to engage my attention in scientific pursuits of almost any kind; but difficult to guard against two abuses—the one of being insensibly drawn from one to another, as I now have from Chronology to Astronomy and from Astronomy to Logarithms—the other of misapplying time, which is essential to the business of life; public and private—

25. Morning visit from Mr Montréal. The cold and rainy Season begins with the new Moon— I wrote a short dispatch, and sent the packet to Mr Lewis to be forwarded this Evening to Mr Willing at Cronstadt— The rest of the day I was engaged with the tables of Logarithms in which I found new difficulties where I thought I had mastered them yesterday—deferred the further examination of them to another day; with the intention to begin again entirely upon Callet. I could not walk after dinner being prevented by the weather, and looked into Lenglet du Fresnoy’s Tablettes Chronologiques.

26. This morning, the first time this Season, I rose with the dawn, and before a full day-light—just at 5 O’Clock—and this Evening after dinner, we had a Stove heated; also the first time this Season— I read prayers for the 15th: Sunday after Trinity. The rest of the day I was engaged in writing on Chronology, and reading in the few Books I have relating to it— Lenglet’s Methode pour étudier l’Histoire, and Count John Potocki give me some notions— But Usher—Petau, Marsham, Pezron—Tournemine—Calmet and many others are not within my reach— I read in the Biographia Britannica about half the life of Usher— This Book is very entertaining, but its method is defective and excessively fatiguing. It is so crowded with Notes, and Notes upon Notes, and notes again upon them that it is scarcely possible to preserve the thread of the narrative. The antients never wrote notes, and it would be a good principle if they were entirely exploded from all literary composition— A writer should have the art of introducing every thing he has to say into the body of his work— Better a digression than a Commentary— Every note, is a digression, and a violation of the principle of unity— It is an excrescence upon the body; a mole, a wart or a wen, according to its extent— The Biographia Britannica loads every one of its personages with them of all kinds.— It is after the fashion of Boyle; but none the better, for that.— Mr Gallatin spent part of the Evening with us.

27. Received letters from Mr Beasley and Mr Speyer— They only inclined me to apply more closely to Chronology, and to the Logarithms— I finished reading in the Biographia Britannica the life of Usher— I found in one of the notes an account of Thomas Lydiat a name mentioned in Johnson’s Vanity of human Wishes, with an allusion which I had never understood, from not knowing any thing of the man— Read over again Lenglet du Fresnoy’s chapter upon Chronology in his Methode pour étudier l’Histoire; and Count John Potocki’s dissertations. It is my great ignorance of the subject which makes it necessary for me to read over three or four times the same things, in order to retain any thing from them. In the Evening I read further in Lenglet’s Tablettes Chronologiques.

28. Rode with Charles to school, and was confined the remainder of the day to the house by the weather— Had fire for the first time this Season, made in my writing chamber. Morning visit from Mr Montréal— Continued my reading of Chronology and of Logarithms— I also read over part of the first Volume of Goguet’s Origin of Laws, and his dissertation upon Sanchoniatho; and made some further progress in the Tablettes Chronologiques.

29. Snow, all the morning. I rode with Charles to school, and walked home— The day was so cold that I found it impossible to make a proper application to reading—and still more to write— Great part of the morning I was engaged with the History of Astronomy in the first volume of Schubert— From that I passed to the first and second Books of Diodorus Siculus— Mr Bayard and Mr Todd passed part of the Evening with us.— The winter has taken us unawares.

30. On rising this morning I found the roofs of the houses, and the ground covered with Snow, which barely disappeared in the course of the day. I rode with Charles to school and walked home— Received a notification from the Grand-Master of the Ceremonies, for a Te Deum at the Imperial Chapel at half past eleven this Morning, for the Victory of the Prince Royal of Sweden at Denne witz the 6th: of this Month— We went at the hour, and mustered only four Ministers of the Corps Diplomatique— The Duke de Serra-Capriola, Count Maistre, and Mr Bardaxi; who told me that he should go out to-morrow, on the road to Abo, to meet his Lady, who has passed through Gothenburg. These Gentlemen all arrived so late, that the Empresses waited for them some time to begin the Ceremony. Prince Alexander Galitzin, the Minister of religious worship, observed that we were few in number; but that it was an occasion for judging by the quality, and not by the quantity. That there had been sometimes here a numerous Corps Diplomatique; but . . . The Prince spoke also of his exile, by the Emperor Paul; the object of which was to remove him from the person of the Grand-Duke Alexander— He was ordered to reside at Moscow, and not to go without the bounds of the City; a restriction which was nothing in Winter; but which he found very disagreeable during two Summers.— The Minister at War read from a printed Gazette a very long Bulletin of
the Crown-Prince of Sweden, which has been published these ten days. The Te-Deum was short, and the company not so exulting as at some other times— The Courier that brought the order left the Head-Quarters at Töplitz the 14th: Nothing of importance had happened in that quarter since the affairs that finished by the Destruction of Van Damme’s Corps. 30. August. I asked Count Maistre if he had Petau’s Chronological works, or could tell me where I could borrow them— He has the Rationarium Temporum, and promised to lend it to me; but he has not the Doctrina Temporum, the work that I chiefly wanted— When I came home I found a note from Mr Victor de Tracy, who had called upon me to thank me, for having obtained the permission to come here— Mr Barthe and Mr Clapier came in soon after— Mr Barthe intends to go to Gothenburg in about a fortnight to proceed thence to America; he asked me to obtain for him a Courier’s Passport, which I promised— I received a letter from Mr Beasley, and a Quadruplicate of the dispatch from the Secretary of State of 23 June— After dinner I called at the lodgings of my Colleagues, but they were at the Theatre— Mr Dallas only was at home, and Mr Harris was with him—when I came home I found Mr: Lewis, who sat with us untill near midnight.

Day. I have risen between 5 and 7—and conclude it impracticable to accomplish a greater degree of regularity— The last week I have been punctual within half an hour of five— I read, for about half an hour, and then pursue Chronological enquiries, or write my Journal—at a quarter past Eight I go with Charles to school, and return just before ten. Breakfast. Read, write or receive visitors untill 5 in the afternoon— Walk an hour after dinner— Read an hour or two more— Sit with Evening visitors or with the family the rest of the Evening, which when we have no company, I finish between 9 and 10. it goes on to 11 or 12 when there are visitors; and that produces a corresponding variation of the rising hours in the morning. My health is infirm, and writing becomes daily more difficult and painful.
